description.text:
Made this computer wheel so I could roll my computer case around. Works pretty well. The wheel portion is separate than from the stand thing. Basically you screw the stand thing in to the computer case where the rubber foot used to go and then slip the wheel on it. The stand part can be customized to fit any case.

This design also allows any surface to have wheels because all you need to do is drill stand into the platform and then slip on the wheel and your good to go.

Another added benefit is that the wheels size can be changed to fit your needs. It also allows the power supply to be off the ground so that it can breath.

After using the wheels for a couple of weeks it's really nice! No more having to pick the whole thing up to plug a wire in or inspect the back. No more struggle! Now it's just roll it away from the wall a little bit and then deal with the cable and then roll it back. It's soooooo nice! It's the little things in life that matter. ahhhhh.

title: Raspberry Pi 3 B Case for shorter screws
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I needed a Raspberry PI 3 case that is compact and robust, and stumbled upon jayftee's thing, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1427797. Great!

But I soon found out that I didn't have any M2.5x20 screws at hand, and they are not easy to come by. Thus, I modified the case to fit the M2.5x16 screws I could procure. The bottom part is only slightly modified (the nuts are set a little deeper into the casing), for the top part I had to thicken the screw bosses near their base.

This case works for M2.5x16mm screws, but the top part now should be easy to change to fit any screw length between 10 and 20mm.

print_settings.Notes:: Dome/Bowl

description.text:
My Version of the Veggie Slicing Bowl

I kept seeing this Veggie Slicing Bowl video come across my social media feeds and I thought to myself, “I can print that”. So I set out to create a version that I could print on my MP Mini.

This cool little device provides guides so you can cut your vegies in nice even slices. Then, turn the guides 90 degrees and you can Julian or even dice your vegies.

The assembly is made up of two pieces:
.
The Dome/Bowl
This was a little tricky – however I was able to print this with pretty good result without supports.
• Layer Thickness: .175
• Top layers: 4
• Bottom Layers: 4
• Outline Perimeters: 2
• Outline Direction: Inside-out
• Infill Percentage/Pattern: 30%/Grid (With solid diaphragms ever 20 layers)

The Base
This is a basic shape and just about any default settings your printer should do it.
This is a work in progress and I would love some feedback

NOTE: The files that are posted are an update version from the photos of the last print I made. I’ll update those once I have the new version printed

EDIT 2/1/17: Found minor issue wit the dome/bowl. Re-posted the STL

comments.author: BusterCrabb

comments.text: Whenever someone posts a model that in some way comes in contact with food, many people say it's not food safe. Why? Because these prints are porous and there's no way to get the print clean of bacteria. I've seen where some will coat the inside with some sort of paint that's safe for this type of application. From what I've read, you can rid almost anything of nearly 100% of the bacteria by soaking the part in first red wine vinegar, then hydrogen peroxide. These two simple ingredients make for a very powerful and natural anti-bacterial. I use it on my wood cutting board every month.

title: ANET A8 Front and Rear Braces with Holes for Mounting Printer to Bench/Table

description.text:
Front and rear braces with mounting holes. The front is identical to Simhopp's original, with only the addition of mounting holes, and a hole in the side of the center section to allow easier insertion of the bolt if you add the belt tensioner Simhopp designed as well.

The rear is changed quite a bit, and one side extends over to an existing machine screw to prevent the rear acrylic plate from deflecting away with pressure from the stepper motor bracket. It also doesn't carry the load to the middle of the frame. Instead, by using the mounting holes to attach to a solid surface, the load of tightening the belt goes to the solid surface you're attaching to.

I've had them on for about a month now, and I'm sharing the design because I've had no issues whatsoever, and they have worked exceptionally well.

title: Tamiya Truck 1/14 Compatible Low Boy Trailer v1

description.text:
New version 2 here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2210380

I wanted a low boy trailer ever since I got into RC Semis. They are pretty expensive with high shipping charges for intl freight. So I made one.

The goal was to adapt the Tamiya flatbed trailer (https://www.tamiyausa.com/items/radio-control-kits-30/1-14-scale-r-c-tractor-trailer-35100/flatbed-semi-trailer-56306) so hardware and the parts that didn't need to be re-created were easily obtainable. This trailer is available from most retailers in the $170 USD range. For the most part, if you buy a trailer kit and print all these pieces, you'll have everything you need. There may be a few extra fasteners required as I didn't track what I used in addition to the kit as closely as I should have. If you're a bit of a maker or an RC nerd, you should have some spares lying around anyway and will probably get you by.

The rear frame rails are the same on both sides, so mirror that part in your slicer to get the other side.

In addition to that, I used some spare center supports that I had leftover from other kits. If you don't have any of those, you can print a few from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1936011/#files. Its called "support.stl." You may also be able to use the crossbeam from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1903313. Thanks jan1cato!

There is still a bit of flex in the bed and at the rear in the rear adapter. The adpater flex is probably unavoidable with PLA (perhaps some carbon filament would stiffen this up). I may add a few fasteners to the side rails and the bottom aluminum sheet to help combat the flex in the bed. It is still pretty strong. Unless you're loading lead or gold bullion you'll be fine. I'll probably pickup a Bruder bulldozer or other heavy equipment model for a load for this trailer. The center bed is a scale 32' long, which may be longer than most lowboy trailers. I didn't want to require any metal cutting or fab for this project, so I just left it as is. If you wanted to shorten the center section it would be pretty straightforward and wouldn't affect my parts at all.

There are some custom supports under the rear adapter that break away easily.

Prusa i3 mk2

comments.text: Just the pieces that are here. To complete this trailer, it requires purchase of the Tamiya flatbed trailer. I have no plans of making a printable center section as that is basically just a sheet of aluminum. Its long and does not lend itself well to printing 200mm at a time plus i think it would have too much flex. You still have to buy the rear suspension, axles (although they are printable in other thingiverse makes) and wheels / tires. The Tamiya rear bumper / lights / mudflap bracket is also well integrated into the 3D printed parts. You get all this with the trailer kit, so I just went that route.

title: Mostly printed Humongous 3d printer CNC multitool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE
I have not printed anything successfully yet, because the 4 z-axis motors are only getting 1/2 power. So they tend to skipping steps. As a result, it does not raise level. My solution to this problem, is to mount a Mechaduino board on each motor, that should solve the problem. In case you are wondering what a mechaduino board is, it's basically a encoder and motor controller that mounts on the back of any nema 17 or even nema 23 stepper motor, and turns it into a servo/stepper motor. I'll leave a link below. I just need to figure out how to wire it up to the ramps broad, which I hope to do this weekend. I only discovered the mechaduino a few weeks ago, I wish I had known about it when I started, with it I could have used nema 23 motors for the Z axis, and I can put more power to the motors. It's taking me longer then I had excepted, because for a few mouth there I was busy with other things.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SQyKY9fDAi4&index=30&list=WL

I got the printer working still needs some tuneup, I was not able to upload the video of it on this website so here is a link to a youtube video of it https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S0umeOFl_mI
This printer has a built volume of 38''x24''x28'' high. It can easily be made larger or smaller. I got the inspiration for the design from the Mostly Printed CNC http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1671517. I modified the stl files on thinkercad. This one has the 1'' OD rods, I got them from the metal super market online, I used cold rolled DOM steel. For the control unit I use a ramps 1.4, I had to use the E1 motor driver for the z axis, for more power. The bearings I used are the same as the ones for the Mostly Printer CNC, and the bolts for the bearings are also the same.
https://vicious1-com.myshopify.com/collections/parts/products/bearings-608-2rs
https://vicious1.com/blog/parts/

Motors
8 nema 17 4 of then with a gear box, gear ratio 5 to 1.18 http://www.ebay.com/itm/322128759561?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT
Bolts
40 1.25''x5/16-18
16 2''x5/16-18
4 1.5''x5/16-18
16 3''x5/16-18
76 6x32x3/4''
16 6x32x1''
8 1.25''x5/16-18
36 3M-10
76 lock nuts 5/16-18
24 nuts 5/16-18
92 nuts 6x32

4 acme screws 3/4''x36''-6
12 acme nuts 3/4''-6

To built the box I used 3/4'' wood.
For the firmware I used Marlin, with the ramps 1.4, and I had to use the E1 driver to power the z axles for more power. To do this you need to go to the Configuration_adv.h file and go to "// #endif // Z_DUAL_STEPPER_DRIVERS" and remove the // in the front.

author: velvetpig

description.text:
This is to drill the 30* section of the EGR pipe in a 1995 Toyota Landcruiser 1FZ-FE cylinder head, and with just a hand drill and $10 of hardware (if you don't already have it), instead of spending $100 at a machine shop.

You'll need 2 M10x1.25 bolts, (I could only get 3" long ones so I used some spacers), and a 1/2" ID x 5/8" OD x 1.5" long metal sleeve. I didn't bother with a real drill bushing because I'm only making one hole, but you may want to harden it if you foresee doing it again.

This only has to be done on foreign market non-egr heads if you want to pass the dreaded california smog (there is a possibility of passing without doing it, but it is a much smaller chance).

I used a smaller (than stock size) 1/2" bit to maintain the structural integrity of the head (right between this and the mating surface is an extremely common failure point, so I figured more aluminum and less surface area for heat transfer would help it)

print_settings.Notes:: I made the first print with MeltInk PLA @230/60.  I also used a brim to keep the corners of the lid from warping or coming off the bed.

description.text:
I am a longtime fan of puzzle boxes and wanted to make one that uses a magnet to open. This box was inspired by Walter Hsiao's magnetic box. I loved his concept of using opposing polarity magnets as hinges.

Installing HInges: Each hinge uses 2 opposing 1/8in x 1/4in magnets. The reversed polarity creates a 'spring' feel that keeps the magnet extended into the void on the base.

The latch mechanism is comprised of a 1/8in x 1/4in magnet stacked on a 3/16in x 1/32in magnet. This portion goes into the large opening on the latch (back side). Another 1/8in x 1/4in is pressed into the small cover so that when installed it opposes the stacked magnets.

In the top corner of the lid, and top corner of the base, there is a spot for a 1/8in x 1/4in magnet. These are installed opposing and force the lid to pop open when the latch is depressed.

Lastly, a 3/8in x 1/8in magnet is pressed into the 'key' piece. when installed correctly, this should oppose the latch from the outside.

If anyone has any issues installing magnets, I can make a video showing assembly.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RKSp8k5e92w
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=haxnlfi4jQc
https://youtu.be/-gFj_6Xnr70

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

44%

Notes:

I made the first print with MeltInk PLA @230/60. I also used a brim to keep the corners of the lid from warping or coming off the bed.

Where to buy Magnets

Here is a list of the parts needed for the hinge and locking mechanism (Click on Name to go to source):
6x 1/8in x 1/4in N52 Neodymium Magnets
2x 1/8in x 1/8in N52 Neodymium Magnets
2x 3/16in x 1/32in N52 Neodymium Magnets

You will also need a magnet for locking/unlocking the box. There is an included STL file for a key that fits a 3/8in x 1/8in N52 Neodymium Magnet

NOTE: The only magnets that are NOT installed reversed polarity are the 3/16in x 1/32in coupled to the 1/8in x 1/4in that is used for the locking mechanism. All the other magnets need to be installed so that they repel the magnet they are next to - like a spring.

TIP: Large Channel locks (pliers) work great for pressing the magnet into the cap, and pressing the cap into the back of the locking mechanism. Make sure to use something like a thin piece of wood or plastic between the pliers and the lid so you don't scratch or mar it.

TIP: The tolerances on the box didn't leave much wiggle room. When assembling the box, you may need to sand off any edges or bumps that aren't supposed to be there. Additionally, I drill out all holes on the lid, and hand turn a drill bit in the bottom to clear out any debris. In order for the box to assemble and work properly, the magnets need to be able to smoothly move in/out of all voids.

print_settings.Notes:: All parts are printed at 100%. I maxed out resolution for the given diameter, so it is still sliceable in Simplify3D. Other slicers are able to scale it down, but you may get issues with very thin walls if you go too low. Also the lamp body will not fit, when using the projector without the lamp body it will work exactly as v2.

description.text:
This thing adds a simple lamp chassis for my stereographic picture projector v2: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1922547

The projector itself now has a thread to mount it to the chassis which can be easily replaced to experiment with different lamp designs without having to reprint the whole thing. The chassis that is generated allows to mount a LED with a cooler exactly at the north pole and create a simple lamp. I used an 1W and a 10W Highpower-LED, they can be found here: https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00S4U0XL4, https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00A092NY2. The cooler is in the chassis surrounded by plastic, so it probably is not as effective as it could be, but I let the 10W LED run for 3 hours and it only got a little warm. I used this one: https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00NQA1U8C. When you use another cooler you can modify the radius/height in the customizer to make it fit. I don't have any experience in lamp building, so this probably can be improved a lot, but it can also serve as basis for remixing it into something more useful/beautiful. The possibility to simply screw it onto a different chassis helps a lot with this, also it allows to switch the projectors witout building multiple lamps.

The preview is too slow and does not render correctly, so I used a workaround to display a simplified version, the created stl will be correct.
If you want to try the thing locally with OpenSCAD you need to switch the part to "projector" or "lamp" to get the respective part, "preview" is the default. This fiddle can help to generate the image array: http://jsfiddle.net/threonin/6dr8qu41/

I printed everything in 0.3mm, seems to work fine. With higher resolutions you can probably crank out a little more detail, but the difference will not be very big.

Edit: Made some small performance improvements by rewriting screw thread library to use a single polyhedron.

A high res version with 85x85 pixels is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2094215

FlashForge

Other slicers are able to scale it down, but you may get issues with very thin walls if you go too low. Also the lamp body will not fit, when using the projector without the lamp body it will work exactly as v2.

You don't need to edit the fiddle, all you need to do there is to upload the image in the bottom right quadrant and the image should appear next to the button and below it the generated array in a textbox. You copy the contents from the textbox and insert them into the scad file, the latest version is stereographic_projector_v3.2.scad. There you also need to change the part to projector, load the file in OpenSCAD and press F6 there. In the file menu you can then export to stl. The fiddle is only there to convert the image into a format OpenSCAD can understand.

What is it?

This is a printable basketball net.

Why?

There are many playground across America and the rest of the World where the net has been either torn, damaged or stolen from an outdoor basketball court. This printable net enables anyone to print one when they need it. Very few stores actually keep a basketball net in stock so you'd have to order it online.

Instructions

Print 4 bottom edges and at least 96 hoop clips (they are 5 cm in height each). Connect the bottom 4 edges to make the bottoms of the net, and use the clips to make up the top of the net that connects to the basketball rim.

Additional info

What's a basketball net?

MakerBot Replicator

Doesn't Matter

I have a couple 100 year old hand planes that I've bought at estate sales. The handles are usually broken in one way or another, so I modeled a set of good handles that can be printed. These are approximate replacements for Bailey (Stanley) hand planes. They should work for any size, but this one came off a #5 plane.

Edit 3/20/17: This was originally modeled after a #5 Bailey, but I added some of the features of an older Bailey #4 to make it more universal. I also have a #4 Stanley Bailey that this should also work for.

Edit 3/22/17: I also have a #4 Stanley plane that had a much taller knob on the front (also broken) so I modeled that one as well.

comments.text: Nice results. My process was a little convoluted but it worked. I traced a good handle on paper to get the general shape, scanned it and filled it in a photo editor with high contrast. I converted the image to an SVG, imported it into Tinkercad to extrude the shape from the image, resized it to match the original dimensions. I exported the rough STL and rounded the edges with Meshmixer.
comments.author: Jocks

comments.text: I reasoned that the original shape must have been hand made, so I started with a 1"x3.5"x4.5" block, drew a couple of arcs and had the basic shape right off.  From there the square edges were shaped with a 1/2" chamfer and I had the bones of the handle.  The long hole is at 60 degrees.  I'll fit it to my friend's plane on Wednesday and if it fits the field trial will begin :)  I'll take some photos.  It is deliberately in bright green, at his request, so that it can be easily identified on site.

title: Glasses/Frame to work with a VR headset

description.text:
I got a cheap VR headset - I needed reading glasses to use it, but it wasn't designed to be worn with glasses, so I got a very cheap pair of reading glasses, took out the lenses and made a frame for them that would fit in side the VR headset.

Also an experiment in capturing the odd shape of the commercial lens and building a curved item in FreeCAD and printing with a lot of supports.

The PLA must have shrunk a bit, as the frames were just too tight, so needed a cut to get the lens in - but the design still held them well.

Printer:

Reprap Prusa i3 2017 model (from kit)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I tried printing various ways - the one that worked was face down (nose bridge on the plate). Because the frame curves it needs support, I got bad adhesion with the thin support walls, so added a thin raft just to give the supports something to stick to.

The small overhang for the groove that the lens fits in worked fine.

Support needs removing.

As I printed face down, what would usually be the visible side had all the support stuff to clean up - but as it was being fitted straight in to my VR goggles this side just faces the VR eye piece lenses, so it wasn't crucial.

In practice the lenses were too tight a fit (just) so i cut the frame so it could flex more around the lens - the plastic is springy and the groove deep enough that this works fine.

Lots of fun with Gimp, Inkscape, FreeCAD and Cura.

I popped the lenses out of the frame (cheap reading glasses from the £1 shop), took a photo of one against a plain background on my phone, sent it via google photos/drive to my desktop into Gimp.

In Gimp I selected cut out the background, flood-filled the lens to make a silhouette, cut and pasted this into a new inkscape document, did a bitmap trace, simplified and tidied it a bit, scaled it then save it.

I imported the svg into FreeCAD as 'geometry', extruded it as a solid... did various boolean things to make the frames!

In Cura I played around until it looked like it would need least support and best chance of sticking (front down, with a raft).

  • Modified the caps similar to the frame connections, allowing you to press fit nicely or add some glue if you prefer. Either way it holds up well!
  • Added "dual adapter" for those wishing to run a fat double wide version of this!
  • decreased the indent in the cap so it prints a bit nicer, but still a comfy grip.
  • added a ridge for the centre bearing so it sits perfectly centred without guesswork or adjustment
  • Designed for use with 608 bearings.
  • Sketchup file included

description.text:
I am not a fan of yoke mounts due to the bulk so I made a nice lightweight one.

Fits a Piper "Ramshorn" style yoke and is adjustable to suit how high you want the ipad to sit. Allows you to have your iPad plugged in. The iPad snaps into position and is held securely.

Edit: Added a V2 that is a bit beefier and uses gopro sized M5 bolts rather than the ball and socket joints. No longer needs the rubber band as it is much stiffer.

Assembly is done using #4 flat head screws and a rubber band along with a bit of stick on foam.

If anyone wants a version for a different yoke style let me know the dimensions. It does need the wedge to press against something as the ball sockets are not strong enough to hold the full weight of the ipad when tilted all the way over.

description.text:
Meet "Que", the GoboLinux mascot :)

http://gobolinux.org/ - GoboLinux is an alternative Linux distribution which
redefines the entire filesystem hierarchy.

In GoboLinux you don't need a package database because the filesystem is the database: each program resides in its own directory, such as /Programs/Xorg-Lib/7.7 and /Programs/GCC/6.2.0.

I made slight changes to the GoboLinux icon to be able to print it, and it came out great :)

There is a unibody version, if you just want to print it in a single colour, available with or without keyring hole.

If you prefer a multi-coloured version, print the supllied separate body parts (body, hand, beak and feet), with different colours/materials, then just glue them together with some CA glue.

Deltabot 300

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed it in these colours, then glued the parts with CA glue.

Brown = body
Yellow = beak + feet
Black = hand

I used yellow for the beak and feet, so I placed both files in the same slicer gcode, and that helped with printing such small parts.

Or you may print several copies at the same time, like 2 sets of hands, etc.

My printer is still being developed, filament temperatures were also a bit off, and these were made with a 0.8 nozzle, so if you have a 0.4 nozzle and a nicely calibrated printer, they will look even better ;)

description.text:
This is a bracket to mount a MKS Base V1.2 board into a Davinci printer.

OpenScad source code included and should be fairly easy to adapt to other boards or other printers.

Why an MKS Base rather than RAMPS?
Because the power connectors on the RAMPS 1.4 boards aren't rated for the current they pull. If you notice the black soot above electronics bay, that's from when I tested a RAMPS board. The inadequate connectors caused that board to (literally) burst into flames after about an hour of usage and burned a fist-size hole in the surface I was testing in on. MKS Base had the features I wanted, and didn't cost much more than a RAMPS board. It has worked great so far.

Do your self a favor and get something better than a RAMPS board. If I hadn't been nearby,
I likely would've lost my house in the fire.

Printer:

Prussa i3 Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Any (I used a .8 volcano nozzle and .3 layer height

Infill:

15%

Notes:

As long as you can print without warping, any filament should work. I personally used PET-G, but only because it is my "go-to" filament. (Reasonably priced, prints great and doesn't warp, what more can you want?)

Mounting screws

I designed this to be screwed to the DaVinci first, install the board, and then screw it down. However, it holds the board great without any screws. After confirming that normal screws can self thread into the holes, I never actually used the screws to hold the board.

With the aluminum bed from anycubic, the heated bed touches the bottom of the glass. The glass is kept in place by friction from the clips, however both are removable as shown in the photos.
comments.author: koihige

comments.text: What material did you print it in?
comments.author: nickcrow

comments.text: I used PLA. Even if you have the bed heated up for printing ABS (~110°C) it's not high enough a temperature to have an effect on the PLA.
comments.author: nickcrow

comments.text: Does this alter the z-height of the build plate?
comments.author: streaml1ne

comments.text: Yes you lose 6mm or so (the thickness of the heated bed)
comments.author: streaml1ne

comments.text:
How are you finding the position and the clearance on the motherboard and the heated bed?
What are your thoughts on that whole motherboard situation ?
comments.author: Martin_mlc

comments.text:
Anyone else concerned about that - try installing the motherboard upside down. Same place between the horizontal bars, but with the tall components pointing towards the bottom. You end up with a huge gap between the bottom of the bed and the top of the board, and no cables wanting to flex up towards the heated bed.
I'm using the updated mount (metal, no cover over the outside USB area, and the insulating sticker and little riser washers) and I don't know if the same trick works for every mount. But it's worth looking at if you have heat concerns.
comments.author: Martin_mlc

comments.text: I'm not sure I totally understand. But there is clearance between the heated bed and the motherboard, enough to put a firewall between them. I used a scrap of hardboard and cut it to size to sit on top of the steppers. Then I used high temp aluminum tape (the kind used for heating duct work) to cover the hardboard and reflect the heat back to the bed. I have not had any issues with the motherboard overheating. YMMV.
comments.author: Martin_mlc

comments.text: Thanks James for the reply. My friend is printing your gear right now to install the heat bed. Thanks for sharing your file and for the info.

comments.text: Awesome! No problem, I hope they work well for you too.

author: mitchr

description.text:
Hi, I'm Paul. I love the outdoors, but I also love making things. I recently bought a 3D printer and wanted to design something of my own to print. I wanted to make something useful, so I decided to make a fire piston/syringe. If you don't know what this is, it is a fire starter that uses adiabatic compression to ignite a small piece of tinder. To understand more of how they work, or how to use them, there is some very good information online. This is my first model, so I was kind of guessing on the dimensions and shape of the device. I will print and test this as soon as possible and update the model. This is all to say that THIS MODEL MAY NOT WORK! As with anything dealing with fire or high heat, BE CAREFUL!

This model is meant to work with 2, 13mm OD x 9mm ID x 2mm o-rings. These can be found on amazon (or possibly printed in a flexible filament) by searching "13mm x 9mm x 2mm o ring"

Instructions:
-Break away the support structures. Remember the supports under the tab on the smaller cylinder (The tab is located in the hexagonal recess)
-Place the mushroom looking piece into the smaller rod. Make sure the tab inside the rod aligns with the notch in the mushroom. I also recommend some kind of glue here. If the tab breaks, you will need to print in a different, more flexible filament type
-Place 2 o-rings (size specified above) in the 2 groves above the "U" shaped notches

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100

comments.text:
Some feedback for you...
The handle is unnecessarily large and the junction is too small (weak). I recommend just printing directly onto the plunger itself. The tolerance between the cylinder and the plunger is a bit too tight. The o rings can make the seal if you take off about .5mm off the diameter of the plunger.

description.text:
[English]
This star map was made as a part of an installation by ITEDA Mendoza for popularization of Astronomy for Tecnopolis science fair in Argentina, supported by FOPAA (Fundación Observatorio Pierre Auger Argentina).

The challenge of this proposal was to create a 1m diameter star map for people who can see and for the blind, allowing the recognition of what can be observed with the naked eye for a certain month, a day and to certain time.

The star map contains visible stars without a telescope for the southern hemisphere, represented according to their magnitude and allows the identification of the constellations from the names printed in Braille.

The model was splited in several pieces for printing with a standard 20cmx20cm printer. See the part reference image when assembling the printed pieces.

Idea: ITEDA Mendoza
Funded: Fundación Observatorio Pierre Auger Argentina
2D Design: Constantino Baikouzis
3D Design: Julián Castro Bosisio

[Spanish]
Este mapa estelar se realizó como parte de una instalación de ITEDA Mendoza para la popularización de la Astronomía para la feria de ciencia Tecnopolis en Argentina. Fue financiado por FOPAA (Fundación Observatorio Pierre Auger Argentina).

El desafío de esta propuesta fue crear un mapa estelar de 1m de diámetro para las personas que pueden ver y para los ciegos, permitiendo el reconocimiento de lo que se puede observar a simple vista durante un cierto mes, un día y un cierto tiempo.

El mapa estelar contiene estrellas visibles sin telescopio para el hemisferio sur, representadas según su magnitud y permite la identificación de las constelaciones a partir de los nombres impresos en Braille.

El modelo fue dividido en varias piezas para imprimir con una impresora estándar de 20cmx20cm. Consulte la imagen de referencia de la pieza al montar las piezas impresas.

Idea: ITEDA Mendoza
Financiamiento: Fundación Observatorio Pierre Auger Argentina
Diseño 2D: Constantino Baikouzis
Diseño 3D: Julián Castro Bosisio

author: Copp3rTop

description.text: I flattened this comb so it could print easily on an FDM printer with no support and strong tines.

So this was more of a test than anything, but... it worked. File is intended to be sliced just a single layer high, and there are slight overlaps on each square's corner to hold it together. In Simplify 3d, I sliced at 100% infill, reduced my extrusion width (to get it to slice the squares properly), increased the extrusion multiplier, and printed it outside-in on my heated glass bed with PLA. Comes off the bed as a solid sheet with the right settings, but flexible like paper, so you can tape it up against things and spray paint for a cool carbon fiber effect.

print_settings.Notes:: I used a z-hop of 0.2mm because I've found it prevents bumps on inconsistencies on the supports at higher speeds.

and
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1936589

These represent my first forays into creating 3D objects, and as such they are by no means perfect.

I would suggest making the flat 'top' an extra 1-2 mm thicker, and editing a channel down the middle to allow for an elastic band to sit flush with the top instead of jutting out.

title: Anet A8 Basic Y Axis Upgrade
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: SInce I upgraded the X axis in a previous project, I figured that the Y axis should be looked at. The Y axis has the same undersized rods and terrible bearings. I upgraded the bearings with the same bearings I used in the last project, (Ina Model KH0824PP) by just disassembling and re-using the existing metal pillow blocks. I'm sure that there are other high quality bearings of this type on Ebay. I upgraded the rods with 400mm long replacement rods from McMaster Carr part number 6112K45. The original rods are 380mm long, the McMaster rods are slightly longer. Because of this, and instead of cutting the hardened linear way rods, I ended up designing new rod end caps that accommodate the additional 10mm on each side of the printer. The STL for this end cap is provided for this project. WARNING, I found out that the screw holes that currently hold the standard acrylic end caps in place are actually in different locations around the printer! As a result you will have to either expand or re-drill new holes to accommodate the screw in either the frame or the end caps. Kind of a pain, but the acrylic with a sharp drill is easy to drill. I used a 5/32" drill in either the frame or the end cap to enlarge the holes to accommodate the different hole locations. One of the holes at the front of the printer was right on the measured distance, but the rest were all over the map. After the upgrade the printer table moves quieter and smoother and the prints are better as the table has way less play in it. I found that the PLA printed endcap flexes less than the acrylic endcaps which adds regidity to the table support structure.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

80%

Notes:

I used three layers on all sides.

WARNING You will have to make sure that the holes in the frame aligns with the end cap, and if not, you have to enlarge or re-work mounting holes. Someone might want to remix the endcaps to allow for different screw mounting hole locations. If you drill out the hole at the right back side, make sure the drill does not damage the Y axis rear limit switch!
Fusion 360

title: Replacement cable plug for Apple power adapter, with integrated cable saver.

description.text:
Replacement part for when the cable on your Apple power brick splits and frays right next to the adapter, as they are wont to do.

  1. Print part.
  2. Crack open the brick. This is best done by putting the tips of a pair of needle nose pliers in the cutouts under the cable storage hooks and pushing the two halves of the case apart by opening the pliers forcefully.
  3. Cut out the damaged part of the wire, including the old plug.
  4. Thread the wire through the new plug.
  5. Resolder and the cable back together and insulate it.
  6. Glue brick back together.

The integrated cable saver should hopefully keep that from happening again.

title: Pi Score MAME Cabinet

description.text:
It's on like Donkey Kong.

UPDATE 2/3/17: Added blank front panel that can be customized.

Jeremy Williams and I (Sean Charlesworth) recreated the classic Coleco Mini Arcade but updated to house a MAME system - the Pi Score. I designed the five piece cabinet that slots together with dovetails and mimics the vintage original.

Inside Jeremy put together an array of Adafruit parts and a Raspberry Pi 3 to make it go. He also simplified the normally painful wiring of the controls by using an off-the-shelf Bluetooth/USB controller.

The bulk of the parts come from Adafruit with a few from Amazon. A complete list is in the Print Guide PDF

Jeremy and I will be bringing more projects your way on our show Bits to Atoms. You can catch the whole build and behind the scenes on Adam Savage's Tested and VRV.

Special thanks to Steve Lin for letting us rip apart his vintage Donkey Kong.

Notes:

Pro tip for Cura - turn Combing off or to No Skin for a nice, clean front panel. Otherwise, combing will connect every outline with a string and doesn't look so pretty.

HARDWARE

UPDATE 2/2/17 Found nifty right angle HDMI that works better and takes the place of separate cable and right angle connectors.

Parts are also listed in the Printing Guide included with file download.

Adafruit list with bulk of the parts.
8BITDO Gamepad
HDMI Cable
USB Micro Right Angle
32G Micro SD Card
Adhesive Velcro for attaching boards or use double-sided tape

title: Prusia I3 rework/clones extruder cable protector/tray - updated

description.text:
UPDATE : Includes version 2 (ver 2 in the filenames). Differences are as follows :

  1. 0.5mm shorter gap for the cable to snap in to. I had my cable pop out once following modification to my frame which extended my Z axis distance from 107mm to 207mm. I can print tall again!
  2. Increased diameter of top most cylinder by 1mm to increase it's stength.
  3. Widened base piece which sits directly on top of the frame. (Not side pieces.)
  4. Made slightly longer, overall.

If Ver1 is working for you, there's no reason to update to ver 2, I just needed it to better work the cable management for the larger print area.

I have my extruder cable bundled in PET cable for cleanliness (sort of) but there's 14 wires inside it's protecting. I noticed the stands were becoming damaged by the cable sliding up and down the corner of the alluminum frame, so I designed this piece. It has rounded corners on each side the cable can be exposed to. I printed black hatchbox PLA and 215, 0.1mm layers, 20% infill. Glued in place with some brown original gorilla glue. (Seems to work better on the alluminum block than does hot glue.)

Print with minimal supports, but they are required. Designed in 123D, file included in the ZIP.

The diameter between the bracket mounts is 7mm.

title: Anet A8 Snap On Filament Guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I hear that mounting the filament to the frame might make the printer wobble, so I run it from a rack behind the printer or from a dispenser above the printer. I use these simple, quick to print, filament holder on the Anet A8 that snaps on to the top of the printer like a clothespin. Snaps on more securely than anticipated, you can actually lift the printer off of the table by lifting on the guide it stays in place that well. All of the other holders that I have seen either fall off of the printer, or have a slot in them to change the filament that causes the filament to come out of the holder. I figured I should make my own to overcome these two annoying issues. Do you really need the slot since the end of the filament is available during a change anyway? I don't. V2 is an improved design of the rear feeding filament holder, and I have added a second design for a similar unit but works top feeding...

Printer:

Anet A8

No

No

print_settings.Notes:: Print with the lip of the grommet on the bed.

description.text:
Ikea Linnmon table tops do not have pre-drilled holes to route cables through.

This 2" grommet perfectly fits a hole you would drill. I used a 2" hole saw but you could also drill a hole and use a jigsaw if you are careful. Do not drill closer than 1" to any edge, as that part is solid and part of the structure of the unit. The table is filled with corrugated cardboard so be careful when drilling as not much force is required. Put masking tape on the top and bottom before drilling to minimize tearout.

title: Space Race Chess Set
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Cold War saw the United States and Soviet Union in a contest for dominion not only of the Earth, but of the heavens. Superiority in rocketry and space exploration became metrics for the success of their rival political and economic ideologies. The spacecraft and launch vehicles developed by the competing space programs differed wildly in their design philosophy but were remarkably alike in functionality--reflecting the distinct routes followed by the two superpowers in pursuit of the same goals.

Pieces:

              United States           Soviet Union
---------------------------------------------------------
King:            Saturn V                  N1
Queen:             STS                Buran-Energia
Bishop:         Titan IIIE              Vostok-K
Knight:         Apollo CSM            Soyuz Capsule
Rook:          Lunar Module             LK Lander
Pawn:         Mercury Capsule        Vostok Capsule

title: DJI Mavic Pro Clone
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
NOTE - UPDATED VERSION AVAILABLE ON http://diyrc.co.uk
A couple of the photos are from the updated version (LED's at the back).

Following on from my Inspire Clone I decided to have a go at the DJI Mavic.. This time it's a little different as I actually have one to measure and compare with so the clone is even better this time. I've tried to make this an easy print with no support required, all items are rotated ready to print.

Please visit my website for updated versions, build logs and more....

Printed at 0.3 / 30% for speed, although it does seem very strong I'll drop this down to 0.2mm / 30% for final print.

title: Anet A8 Reset Button Motherboard Cover

description.text:
I designed this board cover so that I can easily press the reset button on the motherboard. The spiral cut-out in the centre allows the part to bend and extend to press the button.

As I only use the SD card slot to print (my computer is not next to my printer), I press the reset button to reboot the board after re-inserting the SD card. It is also useful to stop your printer mid print if you have troubles with your first layer for instance.

The trouble is that you can bridge connections with your finger when pressing the tiny switch and also risk transferring static to the components on the board. As the cover is non-conductive plastic, this should negate that issue!

PLA works fine for me and because of the spiral feature I am sure that other tougher plastics would work also.

TO MOUNT:
Unmount the board and turn the machine screws around, the holes in the legs are just tight enough for the screws to bite into and secure the whole assembly to the frame. No need for nuts. Hope it helps!

Post your makes - I'd love to see this on your machines!

description.text:
A full X and Y upgrade for the K8200 3D Drag printer.

Designed to:
Encase the Y Axis cables in a cable chain.
House the Stepper motors with a Damper attached to each.
Replace the X and Y End Stop mechanisms.
Allow for proper tensioning of the Y axis belt (now using a GT2 belt)

Both the motor housings have been designed to work with the two plate damper that is available from many places (See pic).

The cable chain is 14mm x 10mm.

The motors are both fitted with a low tooth count pulley to give higher XY resolution.

The Y End Stop is derived from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:616525 by Area51 but now is a bit chunkier and incorporates the End Stop screw.

I suggest you print both the motor mounts on high/solid infill to give them plenty of rigidity.

For all this to work I did have to rotate the bearing holders on the Y Axis furthest from the motor and reduce the printable Y width from 200mm down to 196mm.

See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2079048 for the compete rebuild

title: Buckle Mounting Frame for Velcro Sandal

description.text:
I bought 2 of these velcro sandals before which has buckle on them to strap the ankle part. This kind of design are very rare and I really like the design of using the velcro,

Using buckle made the strapping much faster in transitioning to just a normal sandal for easy in easy out or fully strapped sandal for feelings like wearing a shoe but a sandal actually.

This is a simple non-destructive mounting frame for the buckle on the straps without the need of unwinding the threads and sewing it again which might lead to destruction of the straps.

NOTE:

  • This was specifically design based on POWER brand or BATA brand with UK size of 7.
  • The buckle was salvaged from my old velcro sandal as well and fitted on this.
  • This frame was fitted 10 hours before this thing was published and not much stress test has been done yet

Installing

Use several zip ties to fasten both the frame and buckle to the straps

description.text:
This is a fidget Spinner that uses standard hexnuts (M8,M10,M12) as weights. These should be glued in place.

There seventeen versions:

M12
-- for a 6000 bearing (10x26x8mm)
-- for a standard 608 skate bearing (8x22x7mm) + compact version (smaller diameter)
-- for a 6900 bearing (10x22x6) + compact version (smaller diameter)
-- all as tri or double spinners
M10
-- for a standard 608 skate bearing (8x22x7mm)
-- as double, tri or quad spinner
M8
-- for a standard 608 skate bearing (8x22x7mm)
-- as a double, tri, quad and penta-spinner

The 6900 bearing has the same height of 6mm as ISO 4035 or ISO 8675 M12 nuts.

The provided bearing caps are meant to be pressed into the center hole of the bearing. If the caps do not fit you can adjust the paramters to your liking here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2083000

EDIT: Added double spinner versions for all three bearing types and sizes
EDIT2: M10 and M8 Spinners added.

This design is a direct derivative of the superb http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1685126 by Charlies3DT.

I have modified the End Stop mount position so that I can use it without the metal extension on the micro switch and added top mounts with bearings for the top of the lead screws. Plus an additional fixing hole on the motor plates.

I have also added anti-kickback nuts. This does mean there are some superfluous screw holes in the Z Carriage plates. But I only added the nuts as an afterthought.
Suggest you print this at high infill to maximise rigidity.

Obviously you need to change your Z Axis steps per mm.

See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2079048 for the compete rebuild

author: txaparrita

title: K8200 E3D Titan Extruder Mount and Fan

description.text:
A mount and for the E3D Titan Extruder fitted with a V6 Hot end and Fan mount for three point cooling.

The mount is derived from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1710719 by o_liviu but elongated to fully hold the motor and with a push fit for the fan duct.

The fan duct is inspired by the research done by http://www.desiquintans.com/coolingtests2 which indicates that a combination of point and area cooling provides the best solution. I have therefor created a duct that has three air routes, half of the output is directed at the Hot End Tip and then a quarter to each of the arms.

The arms are separate with a push fit into the body, for a number of reasons. They can be replaced independently, I am free to modify the arm design, and they are easier to print.

Don't try and print this with anything wider than a 0.4mm nozzle as the duct walls are super thin to get the most from the single fan.

See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2079048 for the compete rebuild

Also see a dual fan version http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2170127

author: pcsentinel

description.text:
Mendel pulleys that use an M3 grub screw and a captive nut. The advantage over the original is that you only need one small flat on the motor shaft, rather than two full length ones that have to be filed to exactly the right size.
Can be used for all three axes.

Ream the holes out to 5mm and 3.5mm, fit the nut and grub screw. File a small flat on the motor shaft where the screw will engage.
I find it best to print three at the same time because it stops the small section getting too hot. If you have a machine that oozes then it may be best to print one at time to avoid strings.

title: 3D Connect Four boardgame / 3D Vier Gewinnt Brettspiel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
3D Tictactoe by Ideabigbang has inspired me to increase the board and I made a 3D version of Connect Four!
The blocks are the same, so you can start with Tictactoe (board size 3x3) and then change to the 3D Connect Four (board size 4x4) or even the 5x5 board size (expert mode).

3D Four Connect
Goal of the game
Goal is to place four game pieces in a row. In this case „in a row“ means either vertically, horizontally or diagonally (2D or 3D). Procedure is the same as with ordinary Connect Four: two players are alternately placing one game piece on the board.
Board size 5x5
Rules are the same as with board size 4x4 but this larger version offers more strategic possibilities and demands a lot of concentration from both players!

DEUTSCH

Das 3D Tictactoe von Ideabigbang hat mich auf die Idee gebracht, das Spielbrett zu erweitern um daraus ein 3D - "Vier Gewinnt" Brettspiel zu machen. Die Spielsteine sind unverändert, man kann mit TicTacToe (Spielfeld: 3x3) beginnen, dann zu 3D "Vier Gewinnt" wechseln (Spielfeld: 4x4) und sich bis zum 5x5 - Spielfeld hochspielen.

3D - Vier Gewinnt
Ziel des Spieles:
Ziel ist es 4 Spielsteine in eine Reihe (vertikal, horizontal oder diagonal in der Fläche bzw. im Raum) zu bekommen, wobei abwechselnd die Spielsteine platziert werden.
Spielbrett 5x5:
Das 5x5 - Spielfeld bietet weitere strategische Möglichkeiten und fordert noch mehr die Konzentration der Spieler.

Printer:

Monoprice MP Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

I recommend different colors for cube and cylinder!

You need...

...for the 4x4 board:
1x 3D_connect-four_board_4x4 (105x105mm)
2x 3D_connect-four_cube
2x 3D_connect-four_cylinder

...for the 5x5 board:
1x 3D_connect-four_board_5x5 (118x118mm)
4x 3D_connect-four_cube
4x 3D_connect-four_cylinder

...for TicTacToe:
1x board from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2032481
1x 3D_connect-four_cube
1x 3D_connect-four_cylinder
vertically horizontally diagonally (2D) diagonally (3D) in height also only 4 on the 4x4 board!

description.text: MotoSkull

The Super Simple Gimbal Mounting plate for various cameras.

I saw several bases for the gimbal, but only one other mounting plate.

This one was extracted from the original PDF, cleaned up and extruded to 4mm.

Here it is at last my finished K8200 upgrade, the easiest way I could do this is through a series of links, so here they are:
Z Axis Upgrade: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2078971
X and Y Axis Upgrade with Cable Management: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2078905

M5 Nut: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1873746

For completeness I also used
turbotommi's profile covers http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:356427
The Quicklock part of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:969358
The Spool Holders by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1075644

Edit: I have also now added extra strength to th Y Axis with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2182348.

Frankly there is now so little of the original left that it shouldn't be called a K8200, since I have now replaced the X and Y motors with 0.9 deg motors and am controlling it all with a DuetWifi board (brilliant) https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2481027 so all thats left is the frame and one motor that I use for the E3D titan extruder, but that will be swapped out soon aswell.

If I had known then what I know now! Well I would have started from scratch, but its about the journey.

EDIT: yet more goodies, I have now added dual E3D Titan Aeros, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2240611/edit

title: Ticket Office and WHS Kiosk
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is essentially a small box in which to keep electronics on a Garden Railway dry.
The "WH Smith $& Son" Kiosk is completely enclosed and should keep things dry. It is based on a traditional UK Newsagents Kiosk as seen at many stations.

The Ticket Office is a different front to add to the kiosk sides, roof and back. It is a free hand interpretation of an old Ticket office.

It is surprising how the photos show up the stringing in the letters... It is much less noticable when in the garden.

The "peg board" electronics base has been designed to fit a NODEMCU (ESP8266) V3 and an " LM7805 Regulator Power Supply Module" with AC input, and a "L9110S H-bridge Stepper Motor Dual DC motor Driver Controller Board". Using the peg board means that the modules can be connected with standard Dupont jumper wires, and means that you can change the wiring or reuse the modules easily.
The V2 nodemcu board is smaller, so I have designed another peg board for that that places the motor driver in the middle, to leave room in the kiosk for the station master.
The boards in the photo are set up to drive two filament light circuits (for the station lights and the kiosk), plus two loco sensors (Hall effect switches) and two Servo drives to drive points at the station. The code is available here https://github.com/dagnall53/ESPWIFIROCNET

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 layers, 0.4 nozzle

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The slots in the front and back sections needed to be much bigger than I expected. It may well be that your printer is better set up, and that you find the tags on the sides are a bit loose in the slots. - Feel free to modify the source drawing if you want.

To get the roof to sit flat on the printer, I made a copy and snapped it to a horizontal surface. This is why there are two roofs in the source plans. You will need supports switched on to print the overhangs on the roof.

I printed in PLA with no troubles or lifting.

The kiosk is held together with Ten 1.7mm by 10mm screws. You will need to drill pilot holes that angle into the centre to make sure that they do not break through outside.
I also drill two holes from the sides into the protruding part of the roof inside, to keep the roof well fixed down.

For the Ticket office I glue an off-cut of transparent plastic behind the windows and kiosk opening to keep rain out.

Balloon whisk is a popular item in the kitchen.
Sometimes it is hard to turn by hand, but I made it easy to use it with an electric motor drill.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/4T6ZZ5rcs5g" ></iframe>
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6829DV3FaEj

Here is an approximate dodecadodecahedron created by a method that avoids overlapping triangles.  
The 20 sets of rhombic clusters on a dodecahedron have been replaced by 20 sets of congruent triangles.  The point where the triangles meet moves in and out along a line passing through the origin dependent on the value of a scale factor. One choice of scale factor makes a dodecadodecahedron; negating that choice results in a dodecahedron.  
OpenSCAD code is included.

A raft and external support helps with the overhang at the base of the dodecadodecahedron.  
A scad file which animates the change between forms is included.
